body:
It seems that failure count of tests increases if the license header is added.
before success: 57, failure: 18, error: 1
after    success: 55, failure: 20, error: 1
@jtulach We should use [NETBEANS-1074] instead of `#1074` because "#" refers to PR or issue of GitHub.

I have fixed all the test errors except ones in `FilesAndAttributesCheck.java`. Looks like the missing Javac is causing problems and Java related templates don't have their iterator:
```
value = org.netbeans.modules.java.source.queries.api.TemplateWizardFactory.create from Templates/GUIForms/OkCancelDialog.java
java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: com.sun.source.tree.DirectiveTree
	at java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass(URLClassLoader.java:381)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:424)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:357)
	at org.netbeans.ProxyClassLoader.loadClass(ProxyClassLoader.java:197)
Caused: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: com.sun.source.tree.DirectiveTree starting from ModuleCL@5e4d08f4[org.netbeans.modules.java.project.ui] with possible defining loaders null and declared parents [ModuleCL@632ea9c3[org.netbeans.modules.classfile], ModuleCL@3f3fe5f6[org.openide.filesystems.nb], ModuleCL@9dc8629[org.netbeans.api.templates], ModuleCL@49fb642d[org.openide.execution], ModuleCL@21b7f02[org.netbeans.modules.project.ant], ModuleCL@2b9afd0e[org.netbeans.modules.project.libraries], org.netbeans.MainImpl$BootClassLoader@2ea6137, ModuleCL@44cea167[org.netbeans.api.progress.nb], ModuleCL@44bb3719[org.netbeans.modules.java.project], ModuleCL@44a261d4[org.netbeans.modules.queries], ...23 more]
	at org.netbeans.ProxyClassLoader.loadClass(ProxyClassLoader.java:199)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:357)
Caused: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: com/sun/source/tree/DirectiveTree
	at org.netbeans.spi.java.project.support.ui.templates.JavaTemplates.createJavaTemplateIterator(JavaTemplates.java:114)
	at org.netbeans.modules.java.source.queriesimpl.TemplateWizardIterator.<init>(TemplateWizardIterator.java:77)
```
It would be better, if this test worked correctly. @jlahoda, do you have any advice?

Once the `DynamicVerifyTest` passes, it is essential (as part of [static analysis and dynamic verification](http://wiki.netbeans.org/FitnessForever#Static_Analysis_and_Dynamic_Verification) concept) to include it in the Travis check.
@junichi11 Unfortunately, no idea. I would not be surprised if they were not used at all.
Thanks.
Thanks, merging.
Agreed, and thanks, that will make the startup smoother.

@tmysik Thanks for your reply.

I'll try to investigate where they are used later.
Please rebuild with changes from #683. Feel free to remove the `AcceptLicense` class then - it should be no longer needed.

@thilina01 It seems that application-client-1.4.xml e.t.c. are template files. So please remove thier license heders, then add them to licenseinfo.xml.
 
see https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/blob/c8c697418cc0bef6ba070b3e157b5b67cc4080a4/j2ee.clientproject/src/org/netbeans/modules/j2ee/clientproject/api/AppClientProjectGenerator.java#L162-L174
Assuming the travis check is OK, I'd propose to integrate... then we can start using ergonomics for our benefits.

The apache projects depend on Java, not the GPLv2-CPE licensed OpenJDK. To make this clear: No I don't like that and I don't like, that the ASF considers the GPLv2-CPE not compatible with the ASFs views, but at this time I won't put time into the fight.

There is a issue open to query whether GPLv2-CPE should considered Category B:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LEGAL-336

If that is resolved, and we can formally depend on OpenJDK/OpenJFX, we can discuss further, because moving to JavaFX has also other consequences and needs to be carefully considered.

Please note: I will not reply here anymore: @junichi11 is right, the discussion should take place on the mailinglist.
Merged, as PR is approved, change is good, @thilina01 is not a committer. Thank you!
Just one question: Does this have consequences for Platform applications? Could they have used the facility to show their "own" license?

For the module discussed here (php.phpdoc.documentation): phpdocdesc does not seem to be used (I grepped through the whole tree and there are only referenced, that don't look like "usage"). So maybe the module should just be purged from the tree? The packaged version is dead (according to wikipedia) and phpDocumentor2 replaced it. If you think we gain anything with the introduction of the ALv2 header to binaries list, feel free to merge, but I don't see the benefit.

For the predefined_vars.zip: That looks like extracts from php.net, these are licensed CC-BY-SA 3.0:
http://de2.php.net/manual/en/copyright.php
which is possible to include:
https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-b

From my POV the license reads a lot like the MIT license. But I would raise this with legal, because there are differences. Here is the reference from OSI:

https://opensource.org/licenses/historical.php
Thank you - could you please also add the images from the EaselDemo file? `EaselDemo/public_html/css/images` and `EaselDemo/public_html/img` are affected.

I've added a few more commits to this pull request, to improve the editor's horizontal scrolling behavior to work well with line wrapping enabled.

I've also confirmed that there are no _new_ broken tests in the editor, editor.lib, and editor.lib2 modules as a result of these commits. Though note that both the editor.lib2 module and the editor module had broken tests before this patch was applied. And the latter modules' tests don't seem to be run by Travis nor Jenkins. (See the email thread on the dev list with the subject "Does Travis and/or Jenkins run the NetBeans test suite?")

@matthiasblaesing some tests in libs.git are failing because they're trying to connect to an external remote host: ssh://vcs-test.cz.oracle.com/srv/git/repo/ which doesn't exist anymore!

It seems very fragile to me for a unit test to rely on an external service, don't you think?
I've submitted about that license to legal-discuss: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LEGAL-400

Thank you @junichi11 
Just realized how to identify template files. :+1:
would love to be ;) :+1:

I found the changeset related to phpdocdesc.zip: https://hg.netbeans.org/web-main/rev/eebf8c598245

This is used no longer. So we should be able to remove this module. Am I wrong?
@junichi11 Correct.
@tmysik Thanks! I'll remove it.

@jtulach There are conflicts. (.travis.yml was modified in #690 )

The parallelization of the build pipelines allows us to assign the ergonomics **dynamic verification** to the faster running batch or even create additional. Optimally without influencing the overall time it takes to verify a PR.
Filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-1145
Folks, during addressing comments by @jtulach , I've found some dead code leftovers - cleaned up by commit 576b351. I think the review is still valid and will proceed with squash/merge.
@matthiasblaesing It seems that license files are not appropriate. Could you have a look at them?

I've just updated the PR to reflect current changes in master. If the tests pass, I'd be glad if this could be integrated.

I know this change only moves `platform` and `harness` modules, but it is very painful to keep track with bigger master changes and merge files in different locations properly. If we just agree with the goal to lower the number of directories in the root of repository (so GitHub UI can display them all without scary messages), then let's integrate this as soon as possible and let migrate (with help of the community) other clusters later.

Apache NetBeans IDE 9.0 seems to work fine with the moved sources.
Really cool. Will merge when checks succeed.
Sorry, will fix predefined_vars-license.txt again. (I've deleted not renamed)
I just misunderstood. It seems that there is no problem. It should be OK.

I understood the rules of the ASF so, that if it is an essantial feature of a product it must not depend on a license, that is incompatible with the rules of the ASF. @jlahoda work went into that direction, namely making nbjavac non-essential and require the user to install it, if he/she wants to.

If we need a javac, that can be distributed with netbeans and has advanced features for the IDE, we might want to look at eclipse java compiler, as [it is EPL licensed](https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/eclipse.jdt). The EPL is not optimal for an apache product, but is cleared ([Category B](https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-b)).
OK, everything looks good. Can I merge (checking one more time just to make sure)?
Thanks!
Thanks!
Thanks!
Thanks!
Thanks!
Thanks!
Thanks!
What's the blocker right now, i.e., what/who should be asked/done to get this done?
@eirikbakke, how far along is this from your point of view? Do you need a review, of what specifically, is it ready to be merged from your point of view, and how confident are you about it?

@matthiasblaesing, please note that a) the Java features can't (reasonably) work on JDK 8 without nb-javac, as they are using the JDK 9 javac's API; b) it is still believed NetBeans works better with nb-javac, and so installing it is suggested to the user even on JDK 9+. When ergonomics is enabling the Java support, then without any further tweaks, after it is enabled, a dialog (on JDK 8) or a "status bar tooltip" would come up suggesting installing nb-javac, which would then require a restart. That feels like a poor user experience. If, while the Java support is being enabled, we can ask the user if he/she wants to install nb-javac, and avoid the restart and further inconvenience, that'd significantly improve the user experience IMO.

Regarding using ecj, even though I wouldn't prevent anyone from looking into that, I personally think it would be an enormous effort, the benefits would be limited, and it may not be a good strategic choice. In any case, I doubt I myself could contribute to that.
I'm good with improving the experience of enabling java support in the IDE, but we need to respect the ASFs requirement, that we can't have a hard-dependency on a GPL artifact.

Let's not restart a discussion that has been resolved: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LEGAL-279: "While Java is an important optional module for NetBeans, and many NetBeans users do use/need it for Java development support, it is not part of the NetBeans core."

+1 to improving the user experience of this, although I still have the concerns raised on the mailing list and not answered yet.  The self-signed warning seems more detrimental to the user experience here?!

And as well as respecting the ASF requirements, we are (effectively) distributing a GPL artefact, and need to respect its license - like being clearer where it comes from and what the specific source code is.
So long as the user is able to explicitly accept the license themselves, in one way or another, everything is fine, see again the issue I referred to above.
OK, merging.
I don't see a reason to not merge this, so I will do that unless there are objections.

@geertjanw this is separate to that - there are ASF requirements and then there are GPL requirements.  The license is a two way thing - my point is we're not being clear to end users _how_ they exercise their rights and with whom (like getting the exact source, which is my own current issue).  Some links in the IDE during the install and on a website page with the required info would probably be fine.

Ah you stepped into a snake nest :-) The files were added in this commit in the review:

http://hg.netbeans.org/releases/rev/09747df6994d

My reading is this: The author did not follow the standards for license files. If I'm not mistaken:

- The jsf12-tlddoc.zip was created from the JSF 1.2 implementation TLD files and thus would be CDDL-1.1 (outside apache this would be CDDL-1.1 and GPLv2 dual-licensed, but the ASF prefers to only refer to the selected license)
- the jslt11-tlddoc.zip was created from the standard.jar released from apache jakarta/taglibs project and looks to be apache license 1.1
- the struts tag file would come from the apache struts project and is ALv2

This is more than a bit messy. At best the tlddoc files would be created with maven artifacts and an ant target created, that does what is described in the `tlddoc/HowGenerateDocumentation.html` file.

Please indicate, if you want to take the additional problems. If not, that is ok and the changes can be merged as is (they improve the situation, but not fix it).
With da64cbe  I think we are done! Once [bug 1147](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-1147) is fixed and once the Javac NBM is changed to not require restart, we can integrate.

Thanks you for the update. This PR got a bit stale, so it would be great if you could squash the current commits and rebase the changes onto current master.

Comments right now:
- for the slf4j library, the name of the license file needs to be aligned with the binary it covers (or you need to place a `Files` header into the license file. So please update the name to `slf4j-api-1.7.2-license.txt`
- the license requires the copyright to be included, so the file needs to be present with the year + names. Add a new license "MIT-SLF4J" or similar to `nbbuild/licenses` and reference that ffrom the license file in the module (the license text also needs to be included)
- the unittest checking for Java7 Extension `CheckJava7ExtensionTest` could be removed (I assume that code was folded into the new version?)
- unittests fail because spelling of message was changed and different file status are reported

The unittests that rely on a remote service are indeed more integration test. You could change them to depend on a property (`jgittesthost` or something like that) to make it possible to run them from CLI, but not be run by default.

Closing this PR as it is incompatible with Java 8 and it was indicated, that there is no intention to fix that. (see comment https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/572#issuecomment-394120138)

Oracle plans to end public support of Java 1.8 in January. I would not hold back newer JDK's due to older. 11 comes out [next month](http://www.java-countdown.xyz/). IMHO its more important to support newer than older. Is Netbeans forward looking or more concerned with legacy compatibility? It is clear Oracle wants to move Java forward faster. I would hope Netbeans is not a IDE holding onto the past.

FYI I also have some 70+ Eclipse packages, maybe close to 100. No where near the amount for Netbeans. At the same time. I have no Java 11 fixes for Eclipse, like I have for Netbeans. Just some food for thought. Its all moot to me, as my packages are pretty different from upstream. But I do not believe I can run NB on JDK 11 presently. Definitely cannot builder under JDK 11. I am running RC1 on 10, it fails on 11. My from source version is still a work in progress. Have some odd issues there I need to resolve.

IMHO if people need to support older JDK's they can use older IDE's, like NB 8.x. Older stuff should not hold back newer. Not when newer is about to be the current release version. Also 11 is a long term support, to replace 8. http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/eol-135779.html
Just stop using RC1 please. Apache NetBeans (incubating) 9.0 has been released, end of last month.

I was wondering about that. I guess the VC3 tag is a release tag. The tagging aspect is still very strange compared to upstream. It would be more clear if there was an official 9.0 tag without any suffix. Or a release, rel, etc. I haven't seen any other use that format, not even other Apache projects.

The version is moot to me as I am mostly doing C development at the moment. I need to work on my package more. I need to make a base package, that just builds enough to run plugin manager. Then can install the rest. As an option to building it all from source. Which I have some [open issues](https://github.com/Obsidian-StudiosInc/os-xtoo/projects/1).

I can't use the release version. I had to go back to RC1. There are no available plugins for the release version, no C/C++ stuff, Darcula, etc. I have some of that packaged. I will have to update my stuff to the VC3 tag building from source to have some of the stuff I need. No clue about the C/C++ stuff, cmake, etc.

Please use the mailinglist for discussions and questions.

Diese Nachricht wurde von meinem Android-Mobiltelefon mit K-9 Mail gesendet.

Ok I was just responding to your saying use release over RC1 here. Also I keep getting removed from the mailing list. Not sure whats going on. I have not had that problem on other apache lists, jclouds, maven and tomcat. Occasionally I get bounce warnings. But never removed. This will be the 3rd time I join the apache nb dev mailing list. Having been removed twice without notification. Some sort of bounce related removal. Not anything a human did. Thus nothing from me on that mailing list in a while.
@brunoflavio-com Can we add the license headers to these .groovy files?

I'd like to point out that there is a huge difference between the supported/working build requirements and supported/working runtime requirements.

Currently, the build needs JDK 8, and the minimal runtime is JDK 8 as well. But the IDE can (at least somehow) run on (dev builds of) JDK 11/12 - I use these runtimes. (Although it will be necessary to do some changes to keep the IDE running on 12 in the future, I am afraid.)

We could change the build process to run on JDK 10/11 (and keep the minimal runtime env as JDK 8, or not), but someone needs to do the work.

Dropping JDK 8 as the minimal runtime environment is not a decision that could be done in a PR - that needs to be discussed on the mailing list, and I suspect there may be folks that still want to run NB on JDK 8, for various reasons.

Regarding Unsafe and --release - as I noted, when I was thinking of this, the idea was to use reflection. I am fairly sure one can use --release 8 and compile code that invokes Unsafe using reflection on JDK 8. Please see classes like java.lang.reflect.Method.
This is great. Im going to try this with the Groovy cluster (but only after the relicensing and other activities related to the 2nd donation have been done and merged, so as to minimize conflicts).

> I can't use the release version. I had to go back to RC1. There are no available plugins for the release version, no C/C++ stuff, Darcula, etc. I have some of that packaged. I will have to update my stuff to the VC3 tag building from source to have some of the stuff I need. No clue about the C/C++ stuff, cmake, etc.

Yes you can: https://blogs.apache.org/netbeans/entry/what-s-happened-to-my

> Also 11 is a long term support, to replace 8.

Without wanting to encourage the chitchat monster on here too much, be aware that there is no free Oracle Java LTS.  And various OpenJDK vendors, such as AdoptOpenJDK, are committed to OpenJDK 8 support as long as 11 (eg. Sept 2022 - https://adoptopenjdk.net/support.html )  So, yes, +1 to no rush to drop Java 8 support, and discussing it on the mailing list when the time is right.
Fixed.
Fixed.
We got two answers. It seems to be OK.
Thanks, merging.
Thanks, merging.
Thanks, merging.

Java 8 has become python 2.7... I am talking about building Netbeans under Java 8. I fail to see why people need to build it under 8. Or the benefit to 9 over 8.x for running on Java 8 or developing Java 8 based applications.

You are welcome to provide a pull request enabling NetBeans to be built under Java 9, 10, and 11. Thats all thats needed, someone to put in the work. Whenever you think to yourself I fail to see why people need to do XYZ in the context of NetBeans, you should instead think I fail to see why I dont invest some time so that people wont need to do XYZ.
Is that not exactly what this PR is? Fixes for JDK 11.

You said, that the changes work with JDK 11+ only. The difference: If you make the build compatible with JDK 8 + 11, everybody will cheer up and I'm the first to congratulate, if you create a build, that can't be build (there is not yet a release of JDK 11), you just break the project.

Yes because of changes in the JDK that are incompatible between Java 8 and 11+. Unsafe is [deprecated](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/9-deprecated-features-3745636.html#JDK-8181442) and location changed, as of Java 9. They just waited till 11 to force it on others. This change does work for JDK 10, the current JDK. Just not Java 8.

Likely have to switch sources or some other means to support 8 and 11+. It is a lot of work to support both via some means. Or cut one off, saying NB needs JDK 10+ to build vs 8. Which would make it more forward looking. Without such changes, next month when JDK 11 is released. The latest Netbeans will not be able to build using the latest/current JDK. We will be right back here again, then instead of now. I do not understand the requirement for the latest Netbeans to be able to build or run under older JDKs. There is NB 8.x For Java 8. The latest NB should be good for 10+, current and upcoming JDKs.

[JDK 11](http://jdk.java.net/11/) has been available for months, just official release is in September. Even [JDK 12](http://jdk.java.net/12/) is available, which I need to start building stuff against. I rather be ready for a new JDK before it releases, then after it releases. Playing catch up after a new JDK release. I had to do a tremendous amount of playing catch up for 9. I did not have that problem for 10, or 11, nor will I with 12. Just need to address the things that break under newer. I rather not fall behind again.
Please lets have this discussion on the dev mailing list, not in a pr.

You want to change the policy of netbeans, that can't be done with a small PR. You have an opinion and I respect that, but at this point you have yet to prove, that you are willing to work on the project.

Your change breaks building on JDK 8 (at least you said so), but you also did not do the work necessary to make the whole project to build on JDK 11. So after your changeset is applied the project is not buildable anymore. That won't fly.

I gave my reasoning, I offered pointers what could be done, others gave points what could be done. I'll lock the conversation here, so that if interest is there, it is moved to the mailinglist.
